Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Collapsing, widespread;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Surprised with an ECTN. The ECT did fail after the test with a real hard shovel pull. It broke across the column @ 108cm. Potentially getting deep enough to make that weak layer from earlier this year hard to trigger but the snowpack still has a ton of energy. We stuck to low angle skiing. Didn't find any instability surrounding the upper 'knife' layer. Moderate winds on the ridge, we got off the ridge and away from the wind slab for the pit.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: In more wind sheltered areas at 11,000' on a west aspect we observed multiple collapsed, shooting cracks, and triggered a SS-AS-R1-D1-O 57cm thick slab 50' wide that ran 150'. HS 77cm, 4F- midpack, the depth hoar was 32cm deep, and the avalanche failed at the top of the fist hard depth hoar.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Shallowest snowpit ever dug @ Spruces.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Last night (Jan. 1), 1-2 inches of new snow fell (.1" SWE). The new snow fell on top of a zipper crust formed by a warm day and subsequent nighttime freezing. Below the crust, nearly a foot of fist (F) to four finger (4F)hardness snow exists, resting on several old crusts to the ground. Total snow height was 29.5 inches. We dug a pit on the southeast flank of Casaval Ridge, near treeline. A weak layer of snow was found 18 in / 45 cm down from the surface. This 4F layer was stubborn to unreactive during compression and extended column tests. While Gray Butte weather station (8,000 feet) reported moderate westerly winds all day, it was surprisingly calm at our location, perhaps because we were in the lee of the ridge, down lower in Avalanche Gulch. A few folks above us made it higher and also reported mellow winds.

User.name: Nick Meyers
User.affil: Mt Shasta Avalanche Center - Shasta/Trinity Nat'l Forest

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: ECTP on the ground was not repeated. When pulling on the column during the second test it easily tipped over failing at the ground. The back wall of the ECT's showed a clean cut to the ground. Facets at the bottom of the snowpack were beginning to chain together but still showed poor structure. J. Reddy was the scribe.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Intense blowing snow at higher elevations (>12.5K) from north-north west evident on neighboring summits and ridgelines. Increasing cloud cover at higher altitudes throughout afternoon. Boot Pen through virtually entire pack.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This was a wind loaded slope right off the PCT dug to see effects of wind loading during and following the 12-28 storm. Recent snow to ground. Still early season low tide conditions.
In this area, the snowpack was not representative of the snowpack we saw on the southerly slopes while ascending, where the snowpack lacked cohesion. Where we dug there was an obvious wind slab.

Dug below ridgetop on a South aspect to assess 'reverse loading' from previous and current North winds. Winds were light to calm at the pit, but moderate from the North above the site. Ground level was very uneven heather, 90cms at the observation wall to 115 in the middle of the test wall.

Location is down in bowl in a relatively thicker snowpack that had some previous wind deposits. You sink to the ground in depth hoar on foot. Most of the snowpack is 40-50 cm deep but this was deeper, which was probably why it was not propagating on ECT. Experienced localized collapses on shallower snowpack areas.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very shallow snowpack - mostly around 50 cm. Very fragile and unstable with lots of collapses felt every 30 feet or so on buried depth hoar in the lower half of the snowpack. Snowpits test consistently propagated upon isolation or with very little provocation.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpit dug next to remotely triggered persistent slab avalanche on Dec 27 failing on Dec 11 pwl. Today, improved stability on Dec 11 layer, but still concern with next large loading event. NCF's have developed on a rain crust from the Dec 25 storm system, they are still reactive at this location. This has also been seen with another avalanche at Webber Peak over the weekend with large propagation failing on top of this crust.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug on North Side of the Ridge, just below the peak. Slope had about 20cm of new snow sitting on a fairly stiff 15cm wind slab. ECTX was a surprise given weak sugary snow in multiple layers. Stiff wind slab in the pit location appears to make weak layer tough to trigger.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Heard "whumpfing" upon our approach through low angle forested terrain with forecaster J. McCurdy.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Brandon triggered this avalanche remotely when he stepped off his skis while digging a pit on a low angle slope about 150 m away. He did an ECT at the trigger location before he stepped off his skis. It failed at the interface between the new and old snow (@ 67cm in this crown profile pit). ECTP 23. Coordinates: 39.41206, -120.31307

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: A splitboarder remotely triggered an avalanche while ascending near the spot where I dug this pit. I remotely triggered another D2 avalanche on an adjacent slope immediately after this pit.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area
We skied slope
Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes
Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug below steep tree island. Overnight strong North winds had cross-loaded the pit location and were still moving some snow. The most recent storm with heavy precip (12/23), had strong S-SE winds, so multiple loading patterns were visible in the area. Interestingly, the moist snow from the early December rain event has been gradually refreezing into a solid layer. It is almost totally refrozen in this location (big change from 4 days ago), but there are still some moist snow layers in the mid-lower snowpack.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; We skied slope
We skied slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit dug in a Ski Area; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Site is open slope BTL flanked by trees, smooth ground, 1 major storm cycle since last ski tours. Objectives were to evaluate layers of concern and test stability. CT results were repeated, failures occurred within larger layers not on evident interfaces. Isolated surface hoar crystals observed in upper failure plane.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Collapsing, localized; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Second pit of the day while looking at baseline conditions. Searching in scoured areas around the terrain you can find copious rocks, sticks, and overall low snow pack. The deposition is scattered as we have had strong winds and general winter weather orography has left numerous lenses of drifted snow in which I dug on for this profile.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Observers: BE,LW
Site Characteristics: Convex slope below tree line in an opening with clear sky view about 80 meters below ridgetop. Windward and sun exposed. Small tree in pit, large trees 3-6M away.
Seemed like a representative location. Snow depth at Alta Guard is 97 cm. I dug in another spot and snow depth and layering was similar but I got ECTN at 60 cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: North winds scoured and impacted a lot of upper exposed North terrain. Other slopes that were sterper and wind loaded had slid on the weak mid-pack facets that were 50cm from the ground on our 110cm pit.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: Array
Collapsing, widespread; Collapsing, localized; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Early season snow blanket most of the San Juan Range early season leaving behind lens of snow. As cold nights and warm days were common melting occurred on SE-SW aspects leaving some isolated areas of snow from October/November and after the recent new storms SPC is setting up for some PS problems that wont be going anywhere quick. 2020 baseline pit for SPC
